text:
Introduction
Indeed, all praise is due to Allah. We praise Him, seek His help, and ask for His forgiveness. We seek refuge in Allah from the evils of our souls and the bad consequences of our deeds. Whomever Allah guides, no one can misguide, and whomever He misguides, no one can guide. I bear witness that there is no deity worthy of worship except Allah alone, having no partner, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger.
{O you who have believed, fear Allah as He should be feared and do not die except as Muslims [in submission to Him].} [Ali 'Imran: 102]
{O you who have believed, fear Allah. And let every soul look to what it has put forth for tomorrow - and fear Allah. Indeed, Allah is Acquainted with what you do.} [Al-Hashr: 18].
To proceed:
The doctrine of belief in the Last Day is one of the fundamental issues of creed brought by Islam, upon which the structure of this creed rests after the issue of the Oneness of Allah (Tawheed). This religion—in creed, concept, character, behavior, law, and system—does not stand except upon it and by it.
True life in Islam extends through time to include the limited period witnessed by humans—the period of worldly life—and the period of the Hereafter, which extends for eternity.
(Since the connection between our life and our life in the Hereafter is strong, as this life serves as the plowing and sowing, and the Hereafter serves as the harvest and reaping, it was necessary for man to know about his life in the Hereafter what would invite him to prepare for it, and to establish his worldly life in a manner that achieves goodness and virtue for him in the Hereafter. And since the Hereafter is unseen (Ghayb) which those with piercing intellects and sighted hearts cannot penetrate its veils, let alone those beneath them, Allah the Exalted took it upon Himself to inform them about their path in the journey after life, and about their inevitable destiny. He blended the discourse on the Hereafter with the discourse on this life in a way that makes them intertwined, to achieve the reformation of souls and their rectification, in a world where many creatures, human and Jinn, toil to mislead the servants and distance them from the path of righteousness) (1).
The importance of this research comes at this time when many people are preoccupied with the world and its enjoyments, forgetting the Last Day. Some writers have begun to cast doubt on the apparent meaning of what the Quran and the Messenger (peace be upon him) reported, or they divert the texts from their apparent meanings, or interpret them allegorically and judge them by their intellects. Indeed, the situation has reached the point where some deny much of what happens in the Hereafter which has been authenticated by reports. Their reliance in this is on rational standards which, if they scrutinized carefully, would reveal their corruption. Had they delved into the sciences of the Hereafter, it would have become clear to them that the Hereafter is not like this world, and that the standards and scales of the Hereafter are different from the situation in this world.

Research Plan:
This research includes an introduction, a preamble, four chapters, and a conclusion.
- As for the Introduction: It includes the importance of this topic and its plan.
- As for the Preamble: I discussed the stages that humans pass through. These stages are:
1 - The First Stage: His life as a fetus.
2 - The Second Stage: His worldly life.
3 - The Third Stage: His life in the Barzakh (Interval).
4 - The Fourth Stage: His life in the Hereafter.
- As for the First Chapter: Faith in the Last Day: It includes three sections:
Section One: I discussed the importance of belief in the Last Day and that it is one of the fundamentals of religion. Also, the realities included in the belief in the Last Day, and the meaning of Faith (Iman) linguistically and legally (in Sharia).
Section Two: I discussed the names of the Last Day and mentioned the evidence for them, and the reason for the multitude of names for the Last Day.
Section Three: I discussed the relationship between belief in the Last Day and belief in the Unseen (Ghayb), clarifying the connection between them, and that belief in the Last Day is belief in the Unseen.
- As for the Second Chapter: Signs of the Hour, it includes four sections:
Section One: The Hour and its signs. I explained the categories of the signs of the Hour and that they are divided into two parts:
1 - Minor Signs of the Hour.
2 - Major Signs of the Hour.
And that some of the Minor Signs have occurred while others have not yet occurred.
Section Two: I discussed the Minor Signs of the Hour.
Section Three: I discussed the Mahdi; because his appearance precedes the appearance of the Major Signs of the Hour. I also clarified the place of his emergence.
Section Four: I discussed the Major Signs of the Hour.
- As for the Third Chapter: The Realities Included in Belief in the Last Day: It includes nine sections:
Section One: The Resurrection (Ba'th). I discussed the meaning of Resurrection, what is intended by it, the evidence for it, the Quran's methods in establishing the Return, and the doubts of those who deny the Resurrection and the refutation against them. I also discussed the Gathering (Hashr) and the differing conditions of people in it, and about the land upon which the servants will be gathered and that it is different from

Preamble: The Stages of Life Humans Pass Through
Man passes through four stages of life (1):
1 - The First Stage: His life as a fetus: The fetus in its mother's womb is a living being; it senses, moves, feels pain, grows, gets sick, and becomes healthy... until it completes the specific time decreed for it. Then it is brought out into this life as a weak child as we see. Allah Almighty says: {And We cause to remain in the wombs what We will for a specified term, then We bring you out as a child} [Al-Hajj: 5].
2 - The Second Stage: His worldly life: Then he moves from the constriction of the womb to this vast life, living a life that has no resemblance to his life in the first stage in his mother's womb. He begins to feed from his mouth, see with his eyes, hear with his ears, grasp with his hands, and walk on his legs. Until he reaches maturity and settles, Allah grants him intellect and gives him knowledge, and he remains in this world until his appointed term... then he dies.
Death is the Minor Resurrection; whoever dies, his resurrection has begun, and his time has come. Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) said: Men from the Bedouins used to come to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and ask him about the Hour. He would look at the youngest of them and say: «If this one lives, decrepitude will not overtake him until your Hour rises upon you» (2). Ibn Kathir (3) said: (The meaning is the passing of their generation and their entry into the world of the Hereafter, for whoever dies has entered into the ruling of the Hereafter. Some people say: "Whoever dies, his resurrection has begun," and this statement is correct in this sense) (4).

When the appointed time comes and a person's life nears its setting, Allah sends the messengers of death to extract the soul that manages and moves the body. Allah says: {And He is the Subjugator over His servants, and He sends over you guardian-angels until, when death comes to one of you, Our messengers take him, and they do not fail [in their duties]} [Al-An'am: 61]. The angels of death come to the believer in a good and beautiful form, and to the disbeliever and hypocrite in a terrifying form. What happens to the deceased at the moment of death is not something we witness or see, although we see its effects. Our Lord, Blessed and Exalted, has told us about the state of the dying person, saying: {Then why, when the soul reaches the throat (83) And you are at that time looking on (84) And We are nearer to him than you, but you do not see (85)} [Al-Waqi'ah: 83-85]. The subject in the verse refers to the soul when it reaches the throat during the agony of death, while those around him look at what he suffers from the stupor of death, even though they do not see the angels extracting his soul. Allah says: {And He is the Subjugator over His servants, and He sends over you guardian-angels until, when death comes to one of you, Our messengers take him, and they do not fail} [Al-An'am: 61]. And He said in the other verse: {No! When the soul reaches the collar bones (26) And it is said, "Who will cure [him]?" (27) And the dying one is certain that it is the [time of] separation (28) And the leg is wound about the leg (29) To your Lord, that Day, will be the procession (30)} [Al-Qiyamah: 26-30]. What reaches the collar bones is the soul. 'Taraqi' is the plural of 'tarqawah', which are the bones between the pit of the throat and the shoulder (1).
The Quran has explicitly stated that the angels give glad tidings to the believer of forgiveness from Allah and [His] pleasure, and give tidings to the disbeliever of Allah's wrath and anger. Allah says: {Indeed, those who have said, "Our Lord is Allah" and then remained on a right course - the angels will descend upon them, [saying], "Do not fear and do not grieve but receive good tidings of Paradise, which you were promised. (30) We were your allies in worldly life and [are so] in the Hereafter. And you will have therein whatever your souls desire, and you will have therein whatever you request [or wish] (31) As accommodation from a Forgiving, Merciful." (32)} [Fussilat: 30-32]. This descent, as stated by a group of leading exegetes including Mujahid (2), happens at the time of death (3).

3 - The Third Stage: His life in the Barzakh (Interval):
When he dies, he moves from this life to a Barzakh life, where the soul separates from the body, and he is either blessed or punished. Allah says: {And the people of Pharaoh were enveloped by the worst of punishment - (45) The Fire, they are exposed to it morning and evening. And the Day the Hour appears [it will be said], "Make the people of Pharaoh enter the severest punishment."} [Ghafir: 45-46]. The Prophet (peace be upon him) passed by two graves and said: «They are being punished, and they are not being punished for something major [difficult to avoid]: as for one of them, he used to go about spreading malicious gossip (namimah), and as for the other, he used not to protect himself from his urine» (1).
The Barzakh is the first world of the Hereafter. Barzakh in the language of the Arabs is the barrier between two things. Allah says: {And He made between them a barrier and a prohibiting partition} [Al-Furqan: 53], meaning a barrier. In the Sharia: It is the abode that follows death until the Resurrection. Allah says: {And behind them is a barrier until the Day they are resurrected} [Al-Mu'minun: 100]. Mujahid said: It is what is between death and resurrection (2).
(The first thing that happens after death is the trial of the grave, for people are tested - meaning examined - in their graves. There is no human who dies, whether buried in the earth, thrown into the sea, eaten by predators, or scattered by the winds, except that he undergoes this trial. He is asked about three things: Who is your Lord? What is your religion? Who is your Prophet? As for the believer, he says: My Lord is Allah, my religion is Islam, and my Prophet is Muhammad. Then a caller calls from the sky: 'My servant has spoken the truth.' Then his grave is expanded for him as far as the eye can see, and it is furnished with furnishings from Paradise, and a door is opened for him to Paradise, so its breeze and bliss come to him. As for the disbeliever or the hypocrite, when asked: Who is your Lord? What is your religion? Who is your Prophet? He says: Hah, Hah, I do not know, I heard people saying something so I said it. Then he is struck with an iron hammer, and he screams a scream which everything hears except the two weight-bearing races - Jinn and Humans - and if they heard it, they would fall unconscious (3)) (4).
Included in the belief in the Last Day is belief in everything the Prophet (peace be upon him) informed about regarding what happens after death,

The commentator of At-Tahawiyyah says: (The reports from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) have reached the level of Tawatur (mass transmission) regarding the confirmation of the punishment of the grave and its bliss for those who deserve it, and the questioning of the two angels. The Sharia does not bring what intellects deem impossible, but the Sharia may bring what baffles intellects. For the return of the soul to the body is not in the manner familiar in this world; rather, it is returned to it in a manner different from the familiar return in this world) (2).
Allah says: {Allah rewards those who fear Him - (31) The ones whom the angels take in death, [being] good and pure; [the angels] will say, "Peace be upon you. Enter Paradise for what you used to do."} [An-Nahl: 31-32]. The indication in this verse regarding the bliss of the grave is His saying: {The ones whom the angels take in death} at the time of their death: {Peace be upon you. Enter Paradise}, and even if they have not entered the Paradise whose width is the heavens and the earth, they have entered the grave which contains bliss from Paradise.
(Indications in the Quran have appeared proving the punishment of the grave. Al-Bukhari (3) titled a chapter in the Book of Funerals for the punishment of the grave, saying: 'Chapter: What came regarding the punishment of the grave,' and he cited in the chapter title the saying of Allah: {And if you could but see when the wrongdoers are in the overwhelming pangs of death while the angels extend their hands, [saying], "Discharge your souls! Today you will be awarded the punishment of [extreme] humiliation for what you used to say against Allah other than the truth and [that] you were, toward His verses, being arrogant."} [Al-An'am: 93], and His saying: {We will punish them twice in this world; then they will be returned to a great punishment.} [At-Tawbah: 101], and His saying: {And the people of Pharaoh were enveloped by the worst of punishment - (45) The Fire, they are exposed to it morning and evening. And the Day the Hour appears [it will be said], "Make the people of Pharaoh enter the severest punishment."} [Ghafir: 45-46].

On the authority of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her): A Jewish woman entered upon her and mentioned the punishment of the grave, saying to her: 'May Allah protect you from the punishment of the grave.' So Aisha asked the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) about the punishment of the grave, and he said: «Yes, the punishment of the grave is true.» Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) said: "I never saw the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) pray a prayer after that except that he sought refuge from the punishment of the grave" (1).
And on the authority of Abdullah bin Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: «When one of you dies, his seat is shown to him morning and evening: if he is from the people of Paradise, then [he sees his seat] among the people of Paradise, and if he is from the people of the Fire, then [he sees his seat] among the people of the Fire. It is said: This is your seat until Allah resurrects you on the Day of Resurrection» (2).
The punishment in the grave is primarily upon the soul, and it may connect to the body. However, being upon the soul does not mean the body receives nothing of it; rather, it must receive something of this punishment or bliss, even if indirectly. Know that the punishment and bliss in the grave are the opposite of the punishment or bliss in this world. For the punishment or bliss in this world is upon the body, and the soul is affected by it, whereas in the Barzakh, the bliss or punishment is upon the soul, and the body is affected by it (3).
Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah (4) says: "The punishment and bliss are upon the soul and the body together by the agreement of Ahlus-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah. The soul experiences bliss and punishment separately from the body, and it experiences punishment while connected to the body, and the body is connected to it. So the bliss and punishment are upon both of them in this state combined, just as it is for the soul separate from the body" (5).
4 - The Fourth Stage: His life in the Hereafter:
Then the Hour begins, people are resurrected, gathered, and held accountable for their deeds: {And among them will be the wretched and the happy. (105) As for those who were wretched, they will be in the Fire. For them therein is [violent] exhaling and inhaling. (106) [They will be] abiding therein as long as the heavens and the earth endure, except what your Lord should will. Indeed, your Lord is an effecter of what He intends. (107) And as for those who were happy, they will be in Paradise, abiding therein as long as the heavens and the earth endure, except what your Lord should will - a gift without interruption. (108)} [Hud: 105-108].

Chapter One
Faith in the Last Day

Section One: The Importance of Faith in the Last Day:
Belief in the Day of Resurrection is one of the fundamentals without which faith is not complete. {Righteousness is not that you turn your faces toward the east or the west, but [true] righteousness is [in] one who believes in Allah, the Last Day, the angels, the Book, and the prophets} [Al-Baqarah: 177].
The Quran has presented various types of sophisticated rhetorical styles to confirm its occurrence in the souls of the servants. Allah says: {He arranges [each] matter; He details the signs that you may, of the meeting with your Lord, be certain.} [Ar-Ra'd: 2].
In some places, the discussion about it is a simple statement. Allah says: {Allah begins creation; then He will repeat it; then to Him you will be returned.} [Ar-Rum: 11], and He says: {And the Day they are returned to Him, He will inform them of what they did.} [An-Nur: 64].
Sometimes He confirms its occurrence with "Inna" (Indeed), as in His saying: {Indeed, the Hour is coming.} [Taha: 15], and sometimes with "Inna" and the "Lam" (Indeed... surely), Allah says: {And indeed, the Hour is coming, so forgive with gracious forgiveness.} [Al-Hijr: 85], and He says: {Indeed, the term of Allah is coming. And He is the Hearing, the Knowing.} [Al-Ankabut: 5].
In some places, He negates doubt and uncertainty regarding its occurrence. Allah says: {Indeed, the Hour is coming - no doubt about it - but most of the people do not believe.} [Ghafir: 59].
In some verses, Allah swears that it is coming and real, sometimes by Himself, Allah says: {Allah - there is no deity except Him. He will surely assemble you for the Day of Resurrection.} [An-Nisa: 87], and sometimes by His great creations, Allah says: {By those [winds] scattering [dust] dispersing (1) And those [clouds] carrying a load [of water] (2) And those [ships] sailing with ease (3) And those [angels] apportioning [each] matter (4) Indeed, what you are promised is true. (5) And indeed, the Recompense is to occur. (6)} [Adh-Dhariyat: 1-6].
In some places, He commands His Messenger (peace be upon him) in the context of arguments and disputes to swear by his Lord, confirming its occurrence: {But those who disbelieve say, "The Hour will not come to us." Say, "Yes, by my Lord, it will surely come to you."} [Saba: 3].
And in some verses, He informs that it is the truth: {Indeed, the promise of Allah is truth, so let not the worldly life deceive you}

Faith (Iman) is a matter of great importance; as it is the foundation upon which happiness in this world and the Hereafter is built. It is one of the greatest levels of religion. When Gabriel came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) in the presence of his companions, he asked him about Islam, Iman, and Ihsan.
«He said: O Muhammad, tell me about Islam. He said: Islam is to testify that there is no deity but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, to establish prayer, to pay Zakat, to fast Ramadan, and to perform Hajj to the House if you are able to find a way.» - Thus he interpreted Islam as performing these five pillars: The two testimonies, establishing prayer, paying Zakat, fasting Ramadan, and Hajj to the House.
«He said: You have spoken the truth. Tell me about Iman. He said: Iman is to believe in Allah, His angels, His books, His messengers, and the Last Day, and to believe in Divine Decree (Qadar), its good and its bad.» - Thus he interpreted Iman as believing in these six pillars: Belief in Allah, His angels, His books, His messengers, the Last Day, and Divine Decree, its good and its bad.
«He said: Tell me about Ihsan. He said: Ihsan is to worship Allah as if you see Him, and if you do not see Him, then indeed He sees you» (2). Thus he clarified that Ihsan is one pillar, which is to worship Allah as if you see Him, and if you do not see Him, then indeed He sees you.
These are the three levels of religion: Islam, then Iman, then Ihsan, and every level has pillars.
A Pillar (Rukn) in the language: with a Damma (on the Ra), is the strongest side and a great matter (3). (The Rukn of a thing: is its side upon which it stands. The Rukn of a house is its side upon which it stands. So Iman stands upon these six pillars; if one of them falls, a person is not a believer in it because he has lost a pillar of the pillars of Iman.

For Iman does not stand except on its pillars, just as a building does not stand except on its pillars. These six pillars are mentioned in the Holy Quran; sometimes they are mentioned all together and sometimes some of them are mentioned. Allah says: {But [true] righteousness is [in] one who believes in Allah, the Last Day, the angels, the Book, and the prophets} [Al-Baqarah: 177]. He - Mighty and Majestic - mentioned in this verse five pillars of the pillars of Iman. And He said: {The Messenger has believed in what was revealed to him from his Lord, and [so have] the believers. All of them have believed in Allah and His angels and His books and His messengers} [Al-Baqarah: 285], mentioning four of them. Sometimes He mentions two of them: Belief in Allah and the Last Day. As for belief in Divine Decree (Qadar), He mentioned it in His saying: {Indeed, all things We created with predestination.} [Al-Qamar: 49], and in His saying: {And He created everything and determined it with [precise] determination.} [Al-Furqan: 2] (1).
Among the evidences for the obligation of belief in the Last Day is His saying: {Then did you think that We created you uselessly and that to Us you would not be returned?} [Al-Mu'minun: 115]. And He said: {Then they are returned to Allah, their true Lord. Unquestionably, His is the judgement, and He is the swiftest of accountants.} [Al-An'am: 62]. Belief in the Last Day includes a set of realities mentioned in the Book and the Sunnah, so belief in all of them is required. These include: the trial of the grave, its punishment and bliss, the Hour and its signs, the Resurrection, the Gathering, the Reckoning and what follows it of reward and punishment, the Path (Sirat), Paradise, and the Fire.

Iman in the language: is ratification/belief (Tasdiq). In Lisan Al-Arab: Iman means Tasdiq, its opposite is denial (Takdhib). It is said: A people believed in him, and a people denied him (1).
Al-Raghib Al-Isfahani (2) (may Allah have mercy on him) said: "The origin of safety (Amn) is tranquility of the soul and the removal of fear" (3).
Iman is the verbal noun of 'Amana' (to believe), 'yu'minu' (he believes), 'imanan' (believing), so he is 'mu'min' (a believer) (4). The origin of 'Amana' is 'A'mana' with two Hamzas, the second being softened (5). It comes from 'Amn' (security/safety) which is the opposite of fear (6).
Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah (may Allah have mercy on him) said in his definition of Iman: "...for its derivation is from 'Amn' which is affirmation and tranquility, and that is only achieved if ratification and submission are established in the heart" (7).
Sheikh Ibn Uthaymeen (8) said: (Iman in the language is acknowledgement of something out of belief in it. Therefore, Iman implies a meaning beyond mere ratification, which is acknowledgement and confession necessitating acceptance of news and submission to rulings) (9).
In the Sharia: (It is speech and action; speech of the heart and the tongue, and action of the heart, the tongue, and the limbs; it increases with obedience and decreases with disobedience) (10).
The Last Day is the Day of Resurrection when people are raised for reckoning and recompense. It was named so because there is no day after it,

Section Two: Names of the Last Day (1)
Allah named that Day in which destruction befalls this world, followed by resurrection and gathering for recompense and account, with many names. A group of scholars paid attention to mentioning these names, and some scholars counted them reaching eighty names as Ibn Hajar (may Allah have mercy on him) says (2).
The most famous of these names are:
1 - The Day of Resurrection (Yawm Al-Qiyamah): This name appears in seventy verses of the Book of Allah. Allah says: {Allah - there is no deity except Him. He will surely assemble you for the Day of Resurrection, about which there is no doubt.} [An-Nisa: 87].

Allah says: {So let those fight in the cause of Allah who sell the life of this world for the Hereafter} [An-Nisa: 74], and He says: {That home of the Hereafter We assign to those who do not desire exaltedness upon the earth or corruption. And the [best] outcome is for the righteous.} [Al-Qasas: 83].

Section Three: The Relationship Between Belief in the Last Day and Belief in the Unseen (Ghayb)
Belief in the Last Day is belief in the Unseen; because no one has witnessed it personally. Rather, Allah Almighty informed us about it through His noble messengers, so its path is the authentic transmission from what came in the Book and the Sunnah.
However, Allah, who informed us about the Last Day, made belief in it obligatory upon us, and made it a pillar of faith, has deposited in human nature the ability to believe in the Unseen and distinguished humans with this matter among the things He distinguished, honored, and favored them with.
Animals live within the limits of what the senses perceive only, and their world is confined to that scope. But Allah Almighty honored man and did not confine him within the limits of what his senses perceive only; rather, He expanded his horizons and broadened them, granting him that characteristic: the ability to believe in what the senses do not perceive. Thus, his soul became more spacious and deeper than the animal, and his horizons became wider and higher.
Allah Almighty honored man and intended elevation for him, making belief in the Unseen the most prominent attribute of the righteous. Allah says: {Alif, Lam, Meem. (1) This is the Book about which there is no doubt, a guidance for those conscious of Allah - (2) Who believe in the unseen, establish prayer, and spend out of what We have provided for them (3)} [Al-Baqarah: 1-3].
Belief in the Last Day is based on belief in the Unseen, but it is not blind faith without evidence. For among the attributes of the "Servants of the Most Merciful" is: {And those who, when reminded of the verses of their Lord, do not fall upon them deaf and blind.} [Al-Furqan: 73]. Rather, it is faith in the truth indicated by evidences even if the senses do not perceive it.
Yes, belief in the Unseen is necessary for belief in Allah and the Last Day, and for that reason, the Quran highlighted it at the forefront of the attributes of the believers. Allah Almighty described the believers in many places in the Quran as those who believe in the Unseen, making this attribute a fundamental rule of faith. Allah says: {Alif, Lam, Meem. (1) This is the Book about which there is no doubt, a guidance for those conscious of Allah - (2) Who believe in the unseen, establish prayer, and spend out of what We have provided for them, (3) And who believe in what has been revealed to you, [O Muhammad], and what was revealed before you, and of the Hereafter they are certain [in faith]. (4) Those are on [right] guidance from their Lord, and it is those who are the successful. (5)} [Al-Baqarah: 1-5].
Belief in the Hereafter is also belief in the Unseen, for the Hour, relative to humans, is Unseen, and what happens therein of resurrection, reckoning, reward, and punishment is all Unseen which the believer believes in confirming the report of Allah, Glory be to Him.
(Many matters of religion, its doctrines, and its rulings are essentially belief in the Unseen. Allah Almighty, relative to us, is Unseen. The Barzakh life and the Hereafter life with its introductions and existences are all Unseen, from the establishment of the Hour to the Resurrection and Gathering, to the Reckoning, the Scale, the writing of human deeds, the Path, Paradise, and Hell... etc. All of this is Unseen that must be believed in. No sooner does a human return to a moment of intellectual contemplation and awakening of conscience than he finds himself swimming with his imagination in the world of the Unseen from which he emerged or in the world of the Unseen that surrounds the sides of his soul and the universe around him, and the Unseen that awaits him and to which he is destined. So the Unseen surrounds him from every side: in the beginning, in the destiny, and in what lies between the beginning and the destiny) (1).

Chapter Two: Signs of the Hour

Section One: The Hour and Its Signs
One of the requirements of belief in the Last Day is belief in the Hour, which is the hour when the worldly life ends with all its conditions and the Resurrection begins with all its terrors.
(Since among the doctrines that must be believed in is the Last Day and what it contains of reward and punishment, and since human vision may not extend beyond this life and its enjoyments, thus forgetting the Last Day and not working for it, Allah placed signs before the Hour indicating its realization and that it will inevitably occur, so that people do not harbor the slightest doubt about it nor let anything distract them from it. It is known that if the Truthful and Trustworthy one (peace be upon him) mentioned something of its signs and people saw the occurrence of that thing, they would know with certainty that the Hour is coming without doubt, so they would work for it, prepare for that Day, and provision themselves with righteous deeds before it is too late and the limited term expires. Allah says: {Lest a soul should say, "Oh [how great is] my regret over what I neglected in regard to Allah and that I was among the mockers." (56) Or [lest] it say, "If only Allah had guided me, I would have been among the righteous." (57) Or [lest] it say when it sees the punishment, "If only I had another turn so I could be among the doers of good." (58)} [Az-Zumar: 56-58]) (1).

Divisions of the Signs of the Hour:
The signs of the Hour are divided into two parts (2):
1 - Minor Signs: These precede the Hour by long periods and are of the customary type, such as the removal of knowledge, the prevalence of ignorance, drinking alcohol, competing in constructing tall buildings... and similar things. Some of them may appear accompanying the Major Signs or after them.
2 - Major Signs: These are the great events that appear near the establishment of the Hour and are unusual in occurrence, such as the appearance of the Dajjal (Antichrist), the descent of Jesus peace be upon him, the emergence of Ya'juj and Ma'juj (Gog and Magog), and the rising of the sun from its west.
Scholars have divided the signs of the Hour regarding their appearance into three sections:
1 - A section that appeared and has passed.
2 - A section that appeared and continues to follow and increase.
3 - A section that has not appeared until now.
The first two sections are from the Minor Signs of the Hour, while the third section includes the Major Signs and some Minor Signs.

Section Two: Minor Signs of the Hour (1)
We mean by this the signs that have occurred and passed and will not reoccur, and those that have not yet occurred. They are many, and we will mention some of them:
1 - The Mission of the Prophet (peace be upon him): He (peace be upon him) informed that his mission is a proof of the proximity of the Hour and that he is the Prophet of the Hour. On the authority of Sahl (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: «I and the Hour have been sent like these two» and he pointed with his two fingers, extending them (2). In a narration by Muslim: «and he joined the index and middle fingers» (3). So the first of the signs of the Hour is the mission of the Prophet (peace be upon him), for he is the last Prophet, so no other Prophet follows him. Only the Resurrection follows him as the middle finger follows the index finger, with no other finger between them or separating one from the other (4).
2 - The Death of the Prophet (peace be upon him): Among the signs of the Hour is the death of the Prophet (peace be upon him). In the Hadith on the authority of Awf bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: «Count six things before the Hour: my death, then the conquest of Jerusalem, then a plague that will take you like the 'qu'as' (a disease) of sheep, then the abundance of wealth such that a man is given one hundred dinars and remains displeased, then a tribulation (fitnah) that will not leave a house of the Arabs except that it enters it, then a truce between you and Banu al-Asfar (the Romans/Byzantines) which they will break, and they will come to you under eighty banners, under each banner twelve thousand» (5).
3 - The Conquest of Jerusalem: Among the signs of the Hour is the conquest of Jerusalem. In the Hadith on the authority of Awf bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: «Count six things before the Hour: ... -and he mentioned among them- the conquest of Jerusalem» (6). Jerusalem was conquered during the caliphate of Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) in the year sixteen of the Hijra, as the Imams of biography have stated. Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) went himself, made peace with its people, opened it, purified it from the Jews and Christians, and built a mosque therein in the direction of the Qibla of Jerusalem (7).
4 - The Plague of Amwas (8):

It came in the previous Hadith of Awf bin Malik, his saying (peace be upon him): «Count six things before the Hour: ... -and he mentioned among them- then a 'mawtan' (1) (great death) that takes you like the 'qu'as' (2) of sheep» (3).
Ibn Hajar said: (It is said that this sign appeared in the plague of Amwas during the caliphate of Umar, and that was after the conquest of Jerusalem) (4).
5 - Abundance of Wealth and Dispensing with Charity: On the authority of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: «The Hour will not be established until wealth becomes abundant among you and overflows, to the point that the owner of wealth will worry about who will accept it from him as charity, and a man will be called to it and say: I have no need for it» (5).
Much of what the Truthful and Trustworthy one (peace be upon him) told us has come true. Wealth became abundant during the time of the Companions (may Allah be pleased with them) due to the conquests that occurred, and they divided the wealth of the Persians and Romans. Wealth overflowed during the time of Umar bin Abdul Aziz (may Allah have mercy on him), such that a man would offer wealth for charity and find no one to accept it. Wealth will also increase at the end of time until a man offers his wealth and the one to whom it is offered says: I have no need for it. This - and Allah knows best - is a reference to what will happen in the time of the Mahdi and Jesus peace be upon him (6) regarding the abundance of wealth and the earth bringing forth its blessings and treasures.
6 - Appearance of Tribulations (Fitan): He (peace be upon him) informed that among the signs of the Hour is the appearance of great tribulations wherein truth becomes confused with falsehood, shaking the faith such that a man becomes a believer in the morning and a disbeliever in the evening, or becomes a believer in the evening and a disbeliever in the morning. Whenever a tribulation appears, the believer says: This is my destruction. Then it clears and another appears, and he says: This one, this one. Tribulations will continue to appear until the Hour is established. Imam Muslim narrated from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: «Hasten to do good deeds before tribulations like pieces of a dark night, a man becomes a believer in the morning and a disbeliever in the evening, or becomes a believer in the evening and a disbeliever in the morning, selling his religion for a worldly gain» (7).

The limitation in the Hadiths does not mean everyone who claimed prophethood absolutely, for they are too many to count. Rather, the intent is those who gained power, raised a doubt, had many followers, and became famous among people (1).
In the two Sahihs on the authority of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace be upon him) who said: «The Hour will not be established until impostors, liars, appear, close to thirty, all of them claiming to be a messenger of Allah» (2).

This occurred in the time of the Companions (may Allah be pleased with them) when Islam and justice spread throughout the lands conquered by Muslims. It will also happen in the time of the Mahdi and Jesus peace be upon him when justice prevails over tyranny and oppression.
9 - Appearance of the Fire of Hijaz: On the authority of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: «The Hour will not be established until a fire emerges from the land of Hijaz which will illuminate the necks of camels in Busra (4)» (5).

We ask Allah the Generous for a good outcome for the Muslims in their affair, and the affair of others, and all their conditions, and for the continuation of kindness and protection towards them. The removal of knowledge occurs through the death of scholars. On the authority of Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas (may Allah be pleased with them both), he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say: «Indeed, Allah does not take away knowledge by snatching it from the people, but He takes away knowledge by taking away the scholars, until when He leaves no scholar, people take ignorant heads [as leaders]. They are asked and they issue fatwas without knowledge, so they go astray and lead others astray» (2).
14 - Increase of Police and Helpers of Oppressors: On the authority of Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: «There will be in this nation at the end of time men having whips like the tails of cows; they go out in the morning under Allah's wrath and return in the evening under His anger» (3). Imam Muslim narrated from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: «Two types of the people of the Fire I have not seen: people with whips like the tails of cows with which they beat the people...» (4).
15 - Spread of Adultery (Zina): Among the signs that have appeared is the prevalence and increase of adultery among people. The Prophet (peace be upon him) informed that this is one of the signs of the Hour. In the two Sahihs on the authority of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: «Indeed from the signs of the Hour... -and he mentioned among them- and adultery will appear» (5).
16 - Spread of Usury (Riba): Among them is the appearance of usury and its spread among people and the lack of concern for consuming the unlawful. In the Hadith on the authority of Ibn Masud (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace be upon him) that he said: «Before the Hour, usury will appear» (6).
17 - Appearance of Musical Instruments and Declaring them Lawful: On the authority of Sahl bin Sa'd that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: «There will be in the end of time swallowing [by the earth], pelting [from the sky], and transmutation.» It was said: When is that, O Messenger of Allah? He said: «When musical instruments and singing girls appear and alcohol is declared lawful» (7).
18 - Excessive Drinking of Alcohol and Declaring it Lawful: Muslim narrated from Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) saying: «From the signs of the Hour... -and he mentioned among them- and alcohol will be drunk» (8). Also, what Ibn Majah narrated from Ubadah bin As-Samit, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: «People from my nation will drink alcohol, calling it by other than its name» (9).
19 - Decoration of Mosques and Boasting about them: On the authority of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: «The Hour will not be established until people boast about mosques» (10).
20 - Competing in Constructing Tall Buildings: On the authority of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: «The Hour will not be established until people compete in constructing tall buildings» (11).
21 - The Slave Girl Giving Birth to Her Mistress: It came in the long Hadith of Gabriel, his saying (peace be upon him): «And I will tell you about its signs: When the slave girl gives birth to her mistress (12)». In a narration by Muslim: «When the slave girl gives birth to her master» (13).
22 - Increase of Killing: On the authority of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: «The Hour will not be established until 'Al-Harj' increases. They said: What is Al-Harj, O Messenger of Allah? He said: Killing, killing...» (14).
23 - Convergence of Time: On the authority of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: «The Hour will not be established... until time converges» (15).

text: Topic Three: The Mahdi (1) Before mentioning these ten major signs, we speak about the Mahdi because his appearance precedes these signs, for he is the one whom the believers will rally around to fight the Dajjal, then Isa (Jesus), peace be upon him, will descend and pray behind him. In the end times, a man from the Ahl al-Bayt (Family of the Prophet) will emerge, through whom Allah will support the religion. He will rule for seven years, filling the earth with justice just as it was filled with tyranny and oppression. The Ummah will enjoy a great blessing during his reign; the earth will bring forth its vegetation, the sky will rain its drops, and wealth will be given without counting. This man's name is like the name of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and his father's name is like the name of the Prophet's father, peace and blessings be upon him, so his name will be Muhammad or Ahmad bin Abdullah. He is from the descendants of Fatima, the daughter of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, then from the offspring of Al-Hasan bin Ali, may Allah be pleased with them. His described physical traits are that he has a broad forehead (2) and an aquiline nose (3)) (4). Place of his emergence: The Mahdi's appearance will be from the East. It came in the Hadith from Thawban, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: «Three will fight at your treasure, each one the son of a Caliph, but it will not go to any of them. Then the black banners will rise from the East, and they will kill you with a killing that no people have ever been killed with - then he mentioned something I do not remember -, then he said: So when you see him, pledge allegiance to him even if you have to crawl over snow, for he is the Caliph of Allah, the Mahdi» (5). Ibn Kathir said: (The praised Mahdi, promised to exist in the end times, his origin and emergence will be from the direction of the East, and allegiance will be pledged to him at the House [Kaaba], as indicated by some Hadiths) (6). About Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: «The Mahdi will come out at the end of my nation; Allah will provide him with rain, the earth will bring forth its vegetation, he will give wealth properly, livestock will increase, and the nation will become great. He will live for seven or eight - meaning Hajj (years) -» (7).

text: Topic Four: The Major Signs of the Hour (1) There are major signs indicating the proximity of the Hour. If they appear, the Hour will follow in their tracks. In Sahih Muslim, from Hudhayfah bin Asid Al-Ghifari who said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, looked out at us while we were discussing. He said: "What are you discussing?" They said: "We are mentioning the Hour." He said: «It will not be established until you see ten signs before it.» He mentioned the Smoke, the Dajjal, the Beast, the rising of the sun from its west, the descent of Isa bin Maryam (Jesus son of Mary), peace be upon him, Ya'juj and Ma'juj (Gog and Magog), and three landslides: a landslide in the East, a landslide in the West, and a landslide in the Arabian Peninsula, and the last of that is a fire emerging from Yemen driving the people to their gathering place» (2). The major signs follow one another in their occurrence; hardly any time separates them. They resemble in their succession the beads of a necklace when its string is cut. From Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: «The signs are beads strung on a string; if the string is cut, they follow one another» (3). The Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, informed that the Great Battle (Al-Malhamah) between the Muslims and the Romans will happen first, then Constantinople will be conquered, then the Dajjal will emerge. Mu'adh bin Jabal, may Allah be pleased with him, narrated that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: «The habitation of Jerusalem is the ruin of Yathrib (Medina), and the ruin of Yathrib is the emergence of the Great Battle, and the emergence of the Great Battle is the conquest of Constantinople, and the conquest of Constantinople is the emergence of the Dajjal» (4). After the emergence of the Dajjal, Isa, peace be upon him, descends and kills the Dajjal, then Ya'juj and Ma'juj emerge in the time of Isa, peace be upon him, and Allah destroys them in his time. The order up to here is clear. As for the rest of the signs, their order is not entirely clear. Yes, the rising of the sun from its west, the emergence of the Beast of the earth, and the emergence of the fire that gathers the people occur after the emergence of the Dajjal, the descent of Isa, peace be upon him, and the emergence of Ya'juj and Ma'juj. But which of them precedes the other? I mean the rising of the sun from its west, the emergence of the Beast, and the Fire gathering people. The Hadith narrated by Muslim in his Sahih from Hudhayfah is explicit that the emergence of the fire that gathers people from Yemen is the last of the signs, for the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, mentioned the ten major signs and said regarding the tenth sign, which is the fire: «And the last of that is a fire emerging from the land of Yemen driving the people to their gathering place» (5).

text: Six signs remain: The rising of the sun from its west, the emergence of the Beast, the Smoke, and the three Landslides. As for the rising of the sun from its west and the emergence of the Beast, they will be after the descent of Isa, peace be upon him, his killing of the Dajjal, and the destruction of Ya'juj and Ma'juj in his era, and after the corruption of people and the fading of Islam, and before the emergence of the fire that gathers people. But which is earlier, the rising of the sun or the emergence of the Beast? That is something that cannot be asserted with certainty due to the lack of certainty from the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, regarding that. In the Hadith of Abdullah bin Amr, may Allah be pleased with him, he heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: «The first of the signs to appear is the rising of the sun from its west and the emergence of the Beast to the people in the forenoon. Whichever of them happens before the other, the other is close on its tracks» (1). It is not permissible to use this Hadith as evidence that the rising of the sun from its west is before the emergence of the Dajjal, the descent of Isa, and the emergence of Ya'juj and Ma'juj because of his saying: «The first of the signs to appear is the rising of the sun»... the Hadith. (What is most likely from the reports is that the emergence of the Dajjal is the first of the major signs signaling the change of general conditions on most of the earth, ending with the death of Isa, peace be upon him. And the rising of the sun from its west is the first of the major signs signaling the change of the upper world, ending with the establishment of the Hour. Perhaps the emergence of the Beast occurs on that day when the sun rises from its west) (2). And Allah knows best. What appears is that the rising of the sun from its west precedes the emergence of the Beast, then the Beast emerges on that day or one close to it. As for the rest of the signs - the three Landslides and the Smoke - we do not know their order among the great signs, for we have not seen authentic texts determining that, and Allah knows best its reality (3). The Major Signs of the Hour: 1 - The False Messiah (Al-Masih Al-Dajjal): The trial of the Dajjal occurs at the end of time and is one of the major signs of the Hour. His trial is one of the greatest trials to pass over humanity throughout its history. For that reason, all Prophets warned their people of his trial, but our Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, warned his nation about him the most. In Sahih Al-Bukhari from Abdullah bin Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, stood among the people, praised Allah with what He is worthy of, then mentioned the Dajjal, and said: «I warn you of him, and there is no Prophet before me except that he warned his people. But I will say to you about him a saying that no Prophet said to his people: He is one-eyed, and indeed Allah is not one-eyed...» (4). He was called Masih (Messiah) because his one eye is wiped (mamsuhah), and the Masih is the one who has no eye

Description of the Dajjal: The Dajjal is a man from the sons of Adam. He has many attributes mentioned in the Hadiths to introduce him to the people and warn them of his evil, so that if he emerges, the believers will recognize him and not be tempted by him. Rather, they will be aware of his attributes which the Truthful One, peace and blessings be upon him, informed of. These attributes distinguish him from other people, so none is deceived by him except the ignorant one upon whom misery has been decreed; we ask Allah for safety. From Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: «While I was sleeping, circumambulating the Kaaba, there was a man of wheatish complexion, lank hair, water dripping - or pouring - from his head. I said: Who is this? They said: The son of Maryam. Then I turned and there was a bulky man, red, curly-haired, one-eyed, as if his eye was a floating grape. They said: This is the Dajjal. The closest of people in resemblance to him is Ibn Qatan» a man from the tribe of Khuza'ah (4). And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: «No Prophet was sent except that he warned his nation of the one-eyed liar. Beware, he is one-eyed and indeed your Lord is not one-eyed, and written between his eyes is Kafir (Disbeliever)» (5). The Dajjal emerges from the East from a Persian land called Khurasan. From Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, told us: «The Dajjal emerges from a land in the East called Khurasan, followed by people whose faces are like hammered shields» (6). The Companions asked the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, about the duration the Dajjal stays on earth. They said: How long will he stay on earth? He said: «Forty days: a day like a year, a day like a month, a day like a week, and the rest of his days are like your days.» We said: O Messenger of Allah, that day which is like a year, will the prayer of one day suffice us in it? He said: «No, estimate for it its measure» (7).

From Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: «There is no land but the Dajjal will tread it, except Mecca and Medina. There is no passage among its passages but there are angels upon it in rows guarding it. Then Medina will shake with its people three times, and every disbeliever and hypocrite will go out to him» (1). Most of the followers of the Dajjal are Jews and women. From Uthman bin Abi Al-As, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: «Most of the followers of the Dajjal are Jews and women» (2). Ibn Sayyad and the Dajjal: Ibn Sayyad was a man from the Jews of Medina, his name was Saf. He resembled the Dajjal in many of his attributes. The opinions of scholars conflicted regarding him: Is he the False Messiah or not? For this reason, Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar strived to reconcile the differing Hadiths, saying: (The closest reconciliation between what the Hadith of Tamim implies and Ibn Sayyad being the Dajjal is: That the Dajjal himself is the one Tamim saw bound, and that Ibn Sayyad was a devil who appeared in the form of the Dajjal during that period, until he went to Isfahan and concealed himself with his companion, until the time destined by Allah Almighty for his emergence comes) (3), and Allah knows best. Sheikh Ibn Uthaymeen, may Allah have mercy on him, said: (The correct view is that Ibn Sayyad is not the Dajjal who will be sent at the end of time. Rather, he is one of the Dajjals (imposters) resembling soothsayers in his fabrication and guessing, but he is not the Dajjal who will be sent when the Hour is established, whom Isa bin Maryam, peace and blessings be upon him, will kill (4). 2 - The Descent of Isa (Jesus), peace be upon him: His description, peace be upon him, came in the narrations, among them what Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, narrated: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: «On the night I was taken on the Night Journey, I met Musa... and he described him until he said: And I met Isa... and he described him saying: Of medium height, red, as if he came out of a Dimas - meaning: the bath -» (5).

text: Description of his descent, peace be upon him: After the emergence of the Dajjal and his corruption in the earth, Allah will send Isa, peace be upon him, and he will descend to the earth. His descent will be at the White Minaret east of Damascus, Syria. He will be wearing two Mahrud (dyed) garments (1), placing his hands on the wings of two angels. If he lowers his head, it drips, and if he raises it, beads like pearls descend from it. It is not permissible for a disbeliever to find the scent of his breath except that he dies, and his breath reaches as far as his sight ends. His descent will be upon the Victorious Group (Al-Ta'ifah Al-Mansurah), which fights for the truth and is gathered to fight the Dajjal. He will descend at the time of the Iqamah for prayer and will pray behind the leader of that group. In the long Hadith of Al-Nawwas bin Sam'an regarding the mention of the emergence of the Dajjal then the descent of Isa, peace be upon him, he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: «Then Allah sends the Messiah son of Mary, and he descends at the White Minaret east of Damascus, between two dyed garments, placing his hands on the wings of two angels. If he lowers his head, it drips, and if he raises it, beads like pearls descend. It is not permissible for a disbeliever to find the scent of his breath except that he dies, and his breath reaches as far as his sight ends. He will seek him - meaning: seek the Dajjal - until he catches him at the gate of Ludd and kills him. Then a people whom Allah has protected from him will come to Isa bin Maryam, and he will wipe their faces and tell them of their ranks in Paradise» (2). How Isa, peace be upon him, will rule: From Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: «How will you be when the son of Mary descends among you and your Imam is from among you?!». Ibn Abi Dhi'b (3) said: Do you know what "your Imam from among you" means? I said: Will you tell me? He said: He will lead you by the Book of your Lord, Blessed and Exalted, and the Sunnah of your Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him (4) -. The meaning is not that he leads them in prayer, but rather the meaning is that he judges among them by the Book of Allah, Blessed and Exalted; meaning he leads them by the Book of Allah Almighty (5). The time of Isa, peace be upon him, is a time of security, peace, and prosperity. Allah sends abundant rain in it, the earth brings forth its fruit and blessing, wealth overflows, and spite, mutual hatred, and envy disappear. From Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: «By Allah, the son of Mary will surely descend as a just ruler; he will break the cross, kill the swine, abolish the Jizyah, and the young she-camels (6) will be left and no one will strive for them. Spite, mutual hatred, and envy will surely disappear, and he will call to wealth, but no one will accept it» (7). Duration of his stay after his descent then his death: As for the duration of Isa's stay, peace be upon him, on earth after his descent, it came in some narrations that he stays for seven years, and in some forty years. From Abdullah bin Amr, may Allah be pleased with them both: «Then Allah sends Isa bin Maryam... then people remain for seven years with no enmity between two people. Then Allah sends a cold wind from the direction of Sham, and no one remains on the face of the earth having an atom's weight of good or faith in his heart except that it takes him» (8). In Abu Dawood: «He will stay on earth forty years, then he will die, and the Muslims will pray over him» (9). Both of these narrations are authentic, and this is problematic; unless the narration of seven years is interpreted as the duration of his stay after his descent, and that is added to his stay on earth before he was raised to the heaven, and his age at that time was thirty-three years according to the well-known view (10), and Allah knows best. 3 - Ya'juj and Ma'juj (Gog and Magog): The origin of Ya'juj and Ma'juj is from humans, from the offspring of Adam and Hawwa (Eve), peace be upon them. What indicates that they are from the offspring of Adam, peace be upon him, is what Al-Bukhari narrated from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: «Allah Almighty says: O Adam! He says: At Your service and at Your pleasure, and good is in Your hands. He says: Bring out the delegation of the Fire. He says: And what is the delegation of the Fire? He says: From every thousand, nine hundred and ninety-nine. At that time the young will turn grey, every pregnant female will drop her load, and you will see the people drunk, yet they are not drunk, but the punishment of Allah is severe.» They said: And which of us is that one? He said: «Rejoice, for from you is one man and from Ya'juj and Ma'juj are a thousand» (11). Allah, Blessed and Exalted, has informed that the barrier built by Dhul-Qarnayn prevents them from emerging {So they were unable to scale it, nor were they able to pierce it (97)} [Al-Kahf: 97]. He informed that this continues until the end of time when the promise of Allah comes, and He permits them to emerge. At that time, the barrier will be leveled, and they will emerge upon the people {But when the promise of my Lord comes, He will make it level, and the promise of my Lord is ever true (98)} [Al-Kahf: 98]. At that time, they will emerge in waves {And We will leave them that Day surging over each other} [Al-Kahf: 99] and that is near the Resurrection and the blowing of the Horn {And the Horn will be blown, and We will assemble them in one assembly (99)} [Al-Kahf: 99]. Allah Almighty said: {Then watch for the Day when the sky will bring a visible smoke (10) Covering the people; this is a painful punishment (11)} [Surah Ad-Dukhan: 10-11]. Regarding what is meant by this smoke? And has it occurred? Or is it among the awaited signs? There are two opinions for the scholars: First: That this smoke is what afflicted Quraysh of hardship and hunger when the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, invoked against them when they did not respond to him, so they began seeing the sky like smoke. Second: That this smoke is among the awaited signs that have not come yet, and it will occur near the establishment of the Hour. What indicates strongly that the Smoke is among the major signs is what Muslim narrated from Hudhayfah bin Asid, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: «It will not be established until you see ten signs before it... - and he mentioned among them - the Smoke» (3). However, some scholars held the view that they are two smokes; one appeared and the other remains, and it is the one that will occur at the end of time (4). text: Chapter Three: The Facts Included in Belief in the Last Day (1) Topic One: The Resurrection (Al-Ba'th) (2) The Quran gave great attention to the scenes of the Day of Resurrection: the Resurrection and the Reckoning, and the Bliss and the Punishment. So that other world which people were promised after this present world did not remain just described, but became pictured and tangible, living and moving, prominent and looming. The Muslims lived in this world a complete life; they saw its scenes and were affected by them. Their hearts beat fast at times, their skins shivered at times, panic flowed in their souls once, and tranquility returned to them another time. Thus, they came to know this world as it was reported in the Book and the Sunnah before the Promised Day. This world is simple in all simplicity, clear as the clarity of the Islamic creed: death and resurrection, bliss and punishment. As for those who believed and did righteous deeds, for them is Paradise with what is in it of bliss. And as for those who disbelieved and denied the meeting with Allah, for them is the Fire with what is in it of hell. There is no intercession there, nor ransom from the punishment, nor the slightest imbalance in the scale of precise justice. Allah Almighty said: {So whoever does an atom's weight of good will see it (7) And whoever does an atom's weight of evil will see it (8)} [Surah Az-Zalzalah: 7-8]. Indeed, the Quran speaks to the believers about the Last Day and embodies it for them as if they see it right now before them, and live its living scenes with their conscience. Indeed, the Quran's miracle in depicting the scenes of the Day of Resurrection reached such an extent that a person feels as if the Day of Resurrection is the standing present, and as if the world is a past that has elapsed and folded away a long time ago. (Belief in Allah and the Last Day includes belief in the Origin and the Return, which is belief in Creation and Resurrection, just as He combined them in His saying: {And of the people are some who say, "We believe in Allah and the Last Day," but they are not believers (8)} [Al-Baqarah: 8], and He Almighty said: {Your creation and your resurrection are only as a single soul} [Luqman: 28]) (3). The intended meaning of Resurrection (Ba'th) is the bodily return, and the reviving of servants on the Day of Return. So when Allah Blessed and Exalted wills the return of the servants and their revival, He commands Israfil, so he blows into the Horn, and the souls return to the bodies, and people stand for the Lord of the Worlds {And the Horn will be blown, and whoever is in the heavens and whoever is on the earth will fall dead except whom Allah wills. Then it will be blown again, and at once they will be standing, looking on (68)} [Az-Zumar: 68]. text: Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, said: I asked the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, about the saying of Allah Almighty: {On the Day the earth will be replaced by another earth, and the heavens [as well]}, so where will the people be? He said: «On the Sirat (Bridge)» (1). The doubt of the deniers of Resurrection and the refutation against them: Since the issue of Resurrection and Reckoning, and the restoration of life to the dead after the disintegration of those bodies and their mixing with parts of the earth, is one of the major issues in which the polytheists went astray and considered its occurrence unlikely, and this unlikelihood necessitated the wonder of the deniers of Resurrection regarding its occurrence from those who say it and believe in its occurrence. Allah Almighty said, clarifying and explaining the wonder of these deniers: {Qaf. By the honored Qur'an. (1) But they wonder that there has come to them a warner from among themselves, and the disbelievers say, "This is an amazing thing. (2) When we have died and become dust, is that a far return?" (3)} [Surah Qaf: 1-3]. The greatest doubt among the deniers of Resurrection is: considering it unlikely to restore bodies after they have been torn apart, crumbled, and then mixed with parts of the earth. As they become envisioned in the form of dust, so how can they be returned to the state they were in before?) (2) Their poet expressed that denial, indicating that talking about it is a myth, saying: Life then death then resurrection ... ** ... is a myth O Umm Amr Does Ibn Kabsha promise me that we will live ... ** ... and how can there be life for owls and skulls (3) Evidences for Resurrection (4): Belief in the Return is indicated by the Book, the Sunnah, Reason, and sound Fitrah (innate nature). There is no validity to what the misguided claim that minds negate the occurrence of Resurrection and Rising, for minds do not prevent its occurrence, and Prophets do not come with what minds deem impossible, even if they come with what baffles the minds.

text: Among the ways of the Quran in affirming the Return is (Reporting the perfection of Allah Almighty's power and the effectiveness of His will, and that nothing incapacitates Him; so restoring servants after their death is one of the individual effects of His power. Among them is reminding servants of the first origin, and that He who created them when they were not a mentioned thing must restore them as He began them. Among them is His reviving of the lifeless dead earth after its death, and that He who revived it will revive the dead. He affirmed that by His power over what is greater than that, which is the creation of the heavens and earth and great creatures. He affirmed that by the vastness of His knowledge and perfection of His wisdom, and that it is not befitting of Him nor good that He leaves His creation in vain, neglected, not commanded nor forbidden, nor rewarded nor punished; and this is a way by which He affirmed Prophethood and the matter of Return. And among what He affirmed Resurrection with: Recompensing the good-doers with their good and the evildoers with their evil, what He reported of His days among past nations and bygone centuries, and how He saved the Prophets and their followers and destroyed those who denied them and denied the Resurrection, and diversified punishments upon them and brought about exemplary punishments on them. This is an expedited recompense and a model of the Hereafter's recompense shown by Allah to His servants so that those who perished would perish upon evidence and those who lived would live upon evidence. Among that is what Allah showed His servants of His reviving the dead in this world, as Allah mentioned regarding the owner of the cow, the thousands of the Children of Israel, the one who passed by a town which had fallen into ruin, the story of Ibrahim the Friend and the birds, Isa bin Maryam reviving the dead, and other things Allah showed His servants in this abode so they know that He is Strong, Possessor of Ability, and that the servants must be returned, and the settlement is either in Paradise or Fire. These meanings Allah initiated and repeated in many places, and Allah knows best) (1). Among the evidences proving Resurrection and Rising are the following: First: The report of the All-Knowing, the All-Aware about the occurrence of Resurrection: The greatest evidence indicating the occurrence of the Return is the report of Allah Blessed and Exalted about that. So whoever believes in Allah, and confirms His Messenger whom He sent, and His Book which He revealed, has no escape from believing in what He informed us of Resurrection, Rising, Recompense, Reckoning, Paradise, and Fire. Allah Blessed and Exalted diversified the styles of reporting to be more impactful on the souls and more emphasized in the hearts. In some places, the talk about it is a bare statement, Allah Almighty said: {Allah begins creation; then He will repeat it; then to Him you will be returned (11)} [Ar-Rum: 11], and He Almighty said: {And the Day they are returned to Him, He will inform them of what they did} [An-Nur: 64]. Sometimes He emphasizes its occurrence with "Inna" (Indeed), like His saying Almighty: {Indeed, the Hour is coming} [Ta-Ha: 15], and sometimes with "Inna" and "Lam", Allah Almighty said: {And indeed, the Hour is coming, so forgive with gracious forgiveness (85)} [Al-Hijr: 85], and He Almighty said: {Indeed, the term of Allah is coming. And He is the Hearing, the Knowing (5)} [Al-Ankabut: 5]. In some places, He negates doubt and skepticism about its occurrence, Allah Almighty said: {Indeed, the Hour is coming, no doubt about it, but most of the people do not believe (59)} [Ghafir: 59]. In some verses, Allah Almighty swears that it is coming and occurring, sometimes by Himself, Allah Almighty said: {Allah - there is no deity except Him. He will surely assemble you for the Day of Resurrection} [An-Nisa: 87], and sometimes by His great creations, Allah Almighty said: {By those [winds] scattering [dust] dispersing (1) And those [clouds] carrying a load [of water] (2) And those [ships] sailing with ease (3) And those [angels] apportioning [each] matter (4) Indeed, what you are promised is true (5) And indeed, the Recompense is to occur (6)} [Surah Adh-Dhariyat: 1-6].

text: In some places, He commands His Messenger in the field of arguments and disputes to swear by his Lord emphasizing its occurrence: {But those who disbelieve say, "The Hour will not come to us." Say, "Yes, by my Lord, it will surely come to you"} [Saba: 3]. In some verses, He informs that it is true {Indeed, the promise of Allah is truth, so let not the worldly life delude you and be not deluded about Allah by the Deceiver} [Surah Fatir: 5] ... to other styles. Second: Reasoning for the Second Creation by the First Creation: Those who ask for proof of Resurrection after death overlook the fact that their creation in this manner is the greatest proof. The One capable of creating them is capable of repeating their creation. Allah Almighty said: {And the human says, "When I have died, am I going to be brought forth alive?" (66) Does man not remember that We created him before, while he was nothing? (67)} [Surah Maryam: 66-67], and He Almighty said: {And it is He who begins creation; then He repeats it, and that is easier for Him. To Him belongs the highest attribute in the heavens and earth. And He is the Exalted in Might, the Wise (27)} [Ar-Rum: 27]. Third: The One capable of creating the Greater is capable of creating what is less than it: Allah Almighty said: {Do they not see that Allah, who created the heavens and earth and did not fail in their creation, is able to give life to the dead? Yes. Indeed, He is over all things competent (33)} [Al-Ahqaf: 33], and He Almighty said: {The creation of the heavens and earth is greater than the creation of} [Ghafir: 57]. Ibn Taymiyyah said: (For it is known by the axiom of intellects that the creation of the heavens and earth is greater than the creation of the likes of the sons of Adam, and the ability to do so is more profound, and that this easier thing is more worthy of possibility and ability than that) (1). Fourth: His Ability, Blessed and Exalted, to transform creation from one state to another: Allah Blessed and Exalted clarified in more than one place that part of the perfection of His Divinity, Lordship, Names, and Attributes is His ability to transform creation from one state to another. Thus, He causes death and gives life, creates and annihilates, brings out the living from the dead, and the dead from the living. Allah Almighty said: {Indeed, Allah is the cleaver of grain and date seeds. He brings the living out of the dead and brings the dead out of the living. That is Allah; so how are you deluded? (95) [He is] the cleaver of daybreak and has made the night for rest and the sun and moon for calculation. That is the determination of the Exalted in Might, the Knowing (96)} [Surah Al-An'am: 95-96]. Indeed, the turning of servants: death then life, then death then life, is a great proof of Allah's power causing souls to submit to His greatness and authority. Allah Almighty said: {How can you disbelieve in Allah when you were lifeless and He brought you to life; then He will cause you to die, then He will bring you [back] to life, and then to Him you will be returned} [Al-Baqarah: 28].

text: Fifth: Reviving some dead in this life: Allah showed His servants the reviving of the dead in this world. Examples of this include: The people of Musa when they said to him: We will not believe you until we see Allah outright, so Allah caused them to die then revived them. Allah Almighty said addressing the Children of Israel: {And [recall] when you said, "O Moses, we will never believe you until we see Allah outright"; so the thunderbolt took you while you were looking on. (55) Then We revived you after your death that perhaps you would be grateful (56)} [Surah Al-Baqarah: 55-56]. And Isa, peace be upon him, used to create from clay the form of a bird then breathe into it, and it would become a bird by Allah's permission, and he used to revive the dead by Allah's permission. Allah Almighty said: {And [make him] a messenger to the Children of Israel, [who will say], 'Indeed I have come to you with a sign from your Lord in that I design for you from clay [that which is] like the form of a bird, then I breathe into it and it becomes a bird by permission of Allah. And I cure the blind and the leper, and I give life to the dead - by permission of Allah. And I inform you of what you eat and what you store in your houses. Indeed in that is a sign for you, if you are believers} [Surah Ali Imran: 49]. Sixth: Striking a parable by reviving the earth with vegetation: The earth is dead and lifeless with no green tree in it, then rain falls upon it, and it stirs living and green with every beautiful pair. The One capable of reviving it after its death is capable of reviving the dead. Allah Almighty said: {And of His signs is that you see the earth stilled, but when We send down upon it rain, it quivers and grows. Indeed, He who has given it life is the Giver of Life to the dead. Indeed, He is over all things competent (39)} [Fussilat: 39]. Seventh: Allah's wisdom requires resurrecting servants for Recompense and Reckoning: Allah's wisdom and justice require that He resurrects His servants to recompense them for what they presented. For Allah created creation for His worship, sent Messengers, and revealed Books to clarify the path by which they worship Him. So among the servants are those who remained steadfast in obedience to Allah and spent themselves and their wealth in that path. And among them are those who refused steadfastness in obedience to Allah, transgressed, and oppressed. Is it fitting after that for the righteous and the wicked to die, and Allah not reward the good-doer for his good and the evildoer for his evil? Allah Almighty said: {Then will We treat the Muslims like the criminals? (35) What is [the matter] with you? How do you judge? (36) Or do you have a scripture in which you learn (37) That indeed for you is whatever you choose?} [Surah Al-Qalam: 35-38]. Indeed, the misguided disbelievers are those who think that the universe was created in vain and falsehood without wisdom, and that there is no difference between the fate of the reforming believer and the corrupting disbeliever, nor between the fate of the pious and the libertine. Allah Almighty said: {And We did not create the heaven and the earth and that between them aimlessly. That is the assumption of those who disbelieve, so woe to those who disbelieve from the Fire. (27) Or should we treat those who believe and do righteous deeds like corrupters in the land? Or should We treat those who fear Allah like the wicked? (28)} [Surah Sad: 27-28].
